content.description: Hydrangea flowers differ in color based on interactions between a pigment in the flower cells and aluminum ions dissolved in water absorbed from the soil. When aluminum ions are present, the pigment is blue; when aluminum ions are absent, the pigment is pink. The amount of aluminum ions the plant can absorb is dependent on the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the soil.
